conclusion: To compare the internal energy at state a and state c, consider the properties of the processes and behavior of an ideal gas.
The diagram shows two adiabatic processes (curved lines) and two isochoric processes (vertical lines).
Adiabatic processes: no heat exchange (Q = 0). Isochoric processes: constant volume (ΔV = 0).
Internal energy (U) of an ideal gas depends only on temperature (T). For a monatomic gas, U = (3/2) nRT.
For an adiabatic process, PV^γ = constant, where γ is the heat capacity ratio. For an isochoric process, P is proportional to T.
State a is at a lower pressure and volume compared to state c.
Process from a to c involves adiabatic expansion (a to b) followed by isochoric process (b to c), so temperature at c is higher than at a.
Since internal energy is proportional to temperature, and temperature at c is higher than at a, internal energy at c is greater than at a.
